{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3489227,"name":"Arjun Bhatia","username":"ABhatia","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/90db22/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-21T21:15:46.380Z","cooked":"

Our team is working on a 2-stage continuous elevator and while we can handle the mechanical/rigging, we are a bit fuzzy on how to control it well. Our basis mainly relies on two seasons controlling arms with Talon SRX + SRX Mag closed loop control on the motor controller. We figure an elevator will be similar.

We are going to use constant force springs to ensure the inner-most stage tops out before the outer stage starts moving (i.e. pull-up to make inner weightless, pull-down to make outer heavier).

While any recommendations would be helpful, my main points of concern are as follows:

  • Since the load changes when the inner stage tops out, do PIDF also need to change? Would we want a limit switch for this? How would the Phoenix implementation look?
  • Would we need a limit switch to check when the entire elevator is at max height? Or is a soft limit usually accurate enough?
  • Encoder setup. Right now we are planning on using two Falcon 500s with a CANcoder on the rope spool shaft. Would this be the right application for FusedCANCoder?

Any example code, especially using Phoenix libraries would also help.

What is the point of the CANcoder? The Falcons internal encoder should have plenty of resolution, particularly since you are gearing it down by a lot. The CANcoder is a good absolute angle encoder, but your winch shaft is going to be making 10s of turns as the elevator goes up, so the CANcoder is not going to give you an absolute position.
